survey.title: Welcome!
survey.desc: Pittsburghers for Public Transit (PPT) knows that transit planning has to happen from the ground up. When our community resources are spent on improving bus service to the Mon Valley and Eastern Suburbs, what improvements are most important? Where do you think the fast bus corridor beyond the East Busway should go? We're giving you an interactive map so you can test it out yourself and give us your recommendation for you and your neighbors. You can also click on the map to select the options. If you haven't yet, see why we're doing this. Together we are making a plan for how to extend the busway benefits through the Mon Valley and Eastern Suburbs with on-street bus infrastructure improvements, and, with your help, identify some previously overlooked sites in the area.

survey.title: How this tool works
survey.desc:
Now for the fun part!

As you work through the survey, you'll see a number of different things appear on the map.

##### The East Busway

![](/static/assets/legend_eb.png)

The East Busway is shown as a solid, purple/fuschia line. Stops along it are shown as white dots with a purple/fuschia outline. The stops are labeled with their names.

##### Proposed Bus Rapid Transit routes

![](/static/assets/legend_brt.png)

Small dashed purple lines indicate the roads where Bus Rapid Transit has been proposed by the Port Authority. Note that some of these routes overlap with the East Busway.

##### Areas of interest

![](/static/assets/legend_areas2.png)

A dashed blue line indicates a general area of interest. These aren't official boundaries, but may sound familiar (such as 'East End', or 'South Hills'). You'll see these in a few questions.

##### Municipal Boundaries

![](/static/assets/legend_communities.png)

These solid blue lines, with a blue background, indicate actual official municipal boundaries. In this survey, you'll only see these for communities in the Mon Valley and Eastern Suburbs.

##### Destinations / Points of Interest

![](/static/assets/legend_poi.png)

These dots indicate points of interest: libraries, hospitals, parks, etc. When you see these on the map in one of the questions, you'll only see one category/color at a time. Zoom into the map and labels for these items will appear.

##### Potential Corridors

![](/static/assets/legend_corridor.png)

Dashed orange lines indicate the corridors that PPT thinks might be candidates for future service improvements. These are the corridors we'll ask you about in one question during the survey.

<hr></hr>Pan and zoom around the map with your mouse (or finger, if using a touchscreen device).
Zoom in far enough you'll see all existing transit routes.
Some survey questions let you click on either the map or a checkbox to make a choice.
A map legend is available from the menu above.

survey.title: Select your interest area
survey.content:
The East Busway ends at Swissvale, but that doesn't mean that fast, reliable service beyond the busway isn't possible. PPT is looking at two areas that on-street Bus Rapid Transit from the East Busway could serve: McKeesport and the Mon Valley (south) and Monroeville and Eastern Suburbs (east).

 The idea is that transit street improvements would allow buses from the Mon Valley and the Eastern Suburbs to access the transit network more quickly and reliably (and especially connect to the transit hubs of Downtown, Oakland, and East Liberty), and really improve transportation access to and from these outlying communities.
survey.desc: Select the region you're interested in because you live, work, or travel there often. If you spend a lot of time in both the Mon Valley and Eastern Suburbs, select both.

survey.title: Select the communities you want to travel to or from in that region.
survey.content:
Within your area of interest, select the communities that you:

* need to travel to on a regular basis using transit
* Would like to get to and from on buses to
* think good transit access could be a real benefit for.

Select as many communities as you need—it will help us understand where demand for transit is.

survey.title: What specific destinations should be better served by public transit? Select up to five (5).
survey.content:
What specific destinations are important to you? Search and pick from community destinations in the list below: libraries, schools, grocery stores, etc. Select up to five destinations.

The search box lets you search from destinations we've identified in the region, but you can also search for specific places or addresses that aren't on the list!

Additionally, use the filter box to limit the kinds of places that show on the map and in the pick-list.
survey.desc: Use the search bar to type the name of specific place(s) or address(es) in the box below or pick from important community destinations in the list below: libraries, schools, grocery stores, etc

survey.title: Where do you think the fast bus corridor beyond the East Busway should go?
survey.content:
We think there could be several different ways to provide fast and frequent service to these communities, beyond what is available now.

Take a look at the scenarios below. Each scenario represents a combination of on-street improvements that could make big differences in transit service in this area.

Select one corridor on the map that would best suit *your* needs.
survey.desc: Select one corridor on the map that could best serve your community's needs.

forms.text: Mon Valley via East Busway (P7 Corridor)
forms.desc:
The P7 is already pretty fast, but when the Kenmawr Bridge in Rankin is renovated, the P7 could take the busway all the way to Swissvale and drive quickly through dedicated transit lanes to go all the way to McKeesport.

And what if service were also frequent? This would be great combined with running the P7 all day to provide regular access to and from McKeesport.
forms.detail: Improvements to this corridor would help these existing routes: 52L, 55, 56, 59, 60, 61B, 61C, 71, P7

forms.desc:
This corridor would follow the route of the existing 68, 69, P68, P69, and P76 through Forest Hills, but would have transit street improvements through Wilkinsburg and along Ardmore Blvd and beyond to improve service. 

This corridor would extend south to East Pittsburgh, then across the Westinghouse Bridge and east to North Versailles. From there it would head south to McKeesport.
forms.detail: Improvements to this corridor would help these existing routes: 55, 56, 59, 60, 61A, 61C, 67, 68, 69, 71, 71C, 71D, 79, 86, P12, P16, P2, P67, P68, P69, P7, P71, P76, P78

forms.desc: What if the fast, dedicated bus corridor for the 61C that is planned between Downtown, Oakland, and Squirrel Hill continued all the way to McKeesport? This scenario shows us where that might go: from Squirrel Hill to Homestead, then south to Duquesne and McKeesport.
forms.detail: Improvements to this corridor would help these existing routes: 52L, 53, 53L, 55, 56, 57, 59, 60, 61C, 61D, 64, 93, P7

forms.desc: Beginning at the end of the east busway, this scenario is for a corridor that currently overlaps with several existing rapid routes. From the busway, on-street transit improvements through through Braddock could provide a very busway-like speed and reliability. From there, the on-street improvements would Keystone Commons, Turtle Creek, Wall, Wilmerding, North Versailles, and East McKeesport, before heading south to McKeesport.
forms.detail: Improvements to this corridor would help these existing routes: 55, 56, 59, 60, 61A, 61B, 61C, 68, 69, 71, P68, P69, P7, P76

forms.desc: Beginning at the end of the east busway, this scenario is for a corridor that doesn't currently have much service. From the busway, on-street transit improvements through Braddock to East Pittsburgh could provide a very busway-like speed and reliabilit. The improvements might across the Westinghouse Bridge to North Versailles and East McKeesport, and then south direct to McKeesport.
forms.detail: Improvements to this corridor would help these existing routes: 55, 56, 59, 60, 61A, 61B, 61C, 68, 71, P68, P7, P76

forms.desc: This is a long-term idea for having faster direct buses to the Monroeville and beyond, similar to the current P67, and would be combined with all-day bus service. A bus-only ramp between the busway and the Parkway East (376) could provide buses with access to future bus-only lanes on the Parkway. The route would have street improvements for buses from Route 22 to the Monroeville Mall to make buses faster and reliable. They could end at Monroeville's two regional hospitals (Forbes and UPMC East).
forms.detail: Improvements to this corridor would help these existing routes: 61A, 67, 68, 69, P12, P67, P68, P69, P7, P76

forms.desc:
This scenario follows the spirit of the 2017 East Busway Extension Feasibility Study, in that it connects the end of the East Busway to Monroeville through Turtle Creek. Unlike that study, however, this scenario suggests fast and frequent service could be achieved entirely with existing roads, largely following existing routes.

This corridor assumes that on-street improvements from the end of the East Busway, across a repaired Kenmwar bridge in Rankin, can provide busway-like speed and reliability through Braddock and North Braddock. The improvments in this scenario then follow the route of the existing P68 Braddock Hills Flyer, north to the Monroeville Mall, and then continue on Route 22 towards Monroeville's two regional hospitals (Forbes and UPMC East).
forms.detail: Improvements to this corridor would help these existing routes: 59, 61A, 61B, 67, 68, 69, 71, P67, P68, P69, P7, P76

forms.desc:
This corridor would follow the route of the existing 68, 69, P68, P69, and P76 through Forest Hills, but would have transit street improvements through Wilkinsburg and along Ardmore Blvd and beyond to improve service better.

This corridor would extend south to Turtle Creek, then north along James Road through Monroeville, terminating at the regional hospitals (Forbes and UPMC East) near the intersection of Route 22 and the Turnpike.
forms.detail: Improvements to this corridor would help these existing routes: 59, 61A, 67, 68, 69, 71, 71C, 71D, 79, 86, P12, P16, P2, P67, P68, P69, P7, P71, P76, P78

forms.desc: This corridor would follow the route of the existing 67, but would have transit street improvements through Wilkinsburg and beyond to make service better. This corridor could extend the 67 to Monroeville's two regional hospitals (Forbes and UPMC East), while also including on-street improvements for bus travel that would speed up service.
forms.detail: Improvements to this corridor would help these existing routes: 61A, 67, 68, 69, 71, 71C, 71D, 79, 86, P12, P16, P2, P67, P68, P69, P7, P71, P76, P78

survey.title: Assuming you had an unlimited transit pass, what kind of bus service do you prefer?
survey.content:
Do you prefer routes that are faster and more direct but with fewer stops, or routes that are slower and less direct but stop closer to more destinations? Assume you have an unlimited transit pass. 

There are pros and cons to each approach, but transit planners need to balance these types of service when route planning.

forms.text: Faster and more direct buses, but with more transfers and wider bus stop spacing.
Slower buses with windy routes, but with less need to transfer and closer bus stop spacing.

survey.title: How do you use public transit currently?
survey.content: Do you currently use transit a lot, or a little? When you use it, where do you tend to need to go?

forms.text: No more than once a week
Rarely, maybe a couple times a year

formGroups.desc: How often do you use transit?
What are you typically using transit for?

survey.title: What alternative modes of transportation do you use in addition to transit?

formGroups.desc: If you're not traveling by fixed-route transit, how do you get around?

forms.text: Public transit is not available where I am travelling to/from
No transit service at the times I need it
The stops/stations are hard to get to because of bad or no sidewalks
I usually need to carry too many things
Transit isn't reliable to get me where I'm going on time

formGroups.desc: Why do you use other forms of transportation besides public transit?

survey.title: Thank you!
survey.desc:
Thanks for taking this step in building a Riders' Vision for better transit beyond the East Busway!

**If we're going to make this a happen, we need you.**

Leave your contact information to get involved in the campaign, and we'll reach out to you about next steps.

> *Note that by providing this information you agree that is is OK to be contacted by Pittsburghers for Public Transit. This contact information will not be given or sold to any third party.*

survey.title: Send it!
survey.desc: Press **Submit** below to send this info along. If you want to make any changes, you can hit **Back** button below and modify your answers.
